{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3172334,"name":"Ryan Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:17:28.912Z","cooked":"

I’m attempting to tune a two falcon arm that is controlled using motion magic. Unfortunately, although my current PID values seem to accurately bring the arm to the setpoint, the arm moves relatively slow, far below the speed it could reach with high percent output. Also, note that my set cruise velocity and acceleration are high enough, so this is not the issue.

I began messing with a kF term (which had been set to zero prior), and it successfully made the arm move faster. However, the high kF I used makes the arm oscillate a ton, with raising kD not seeming to have any chance at stopping oscillation completely. Am I doing something wrong? How can I get my arm to move faster (closer to its potential high speed) while also keeping oscillations at a reasonable minimum (right now the size of the oscillations are not even close to reasonable)?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:17:28.912Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":314,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":1610.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"Ryan Elchahal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3172337,"name":"tyler hedge","username":"tylerhedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:21:01.460Z","cooked":"

Can you elaborate on your cruise velocity and acceleration being high enough? I find this statement somewhat dubious… Is your arm never reaching its cruise velocity? Because to me this indicates that your p gain is too low. Also, are you compensating for gravity? Because this would lead to inconsistent behavior.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:21:01.460Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":47.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"tyler hedge","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/2","custom_user_title":"6377 Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172346,"name":"Ryan Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:32:11.972Z","cooked":"

I’ve tested cruise velocity and acceleration, and also, when I raised kF significantly, the arm did indeed hit the cruise velocity (which was sufficiently fast) albeit with high oscillations.

To answer your question, yes, the arm is never reaching its cruise velocity when I used PID without a kF, and when I do use kF the arm reaches the cruise velocity but oscillates way too much.

I do compensate for gravity correctly using an arbitrary feedforward.

Note also: we are using position to control the arm

have you tried increasing kP?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:47:10.351Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":103,"readers_count":102,"score":25.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"tyler hedge","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54521,"username":"Relch06","name":"Ryan Elchahal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/4","custom_user_title":"6377 Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172352,"name":"Ryan Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:48:16.622Z","cooked":"

I have tried increasing kP without a kF value and it has resulted in little to no speed improvement.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:48:16.622Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":24.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"Ryan Elchahal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38127,"username":"tylerhedge","name":"tyler hedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172356,"name":"tyler hedge","username":"tylerhedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T20:52:43.391Z","cooked":"

my advice would be to increase kP more. The usual procedure is to increase kP until the mechanism hits its setpoint and is oscillating in a small, consistent manner then add kD until it no longer oscillates.

I can’t speak to kF in motion magic as well as some other people can, but my understanding is that it really isn’t something you tune in the same way as the other gains. kF is part of the feedback loop, it gives you a starting point by guessing at the relationship between desired velocity and % output.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T20:52:43.391Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":98,"readers_count":97,"score":29.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"tyler hedge","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54521,"username":"Relch06","name":"Ryan Elchahal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/6","custom_user_title":"6377 Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172365,"name":"Ryan Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T21:02:07.763Z","cooked":"

I’m aware of the standard PID procedure, and I’ve successfully PID tuned (without a kF term) to a setpoint with little oscillation. However, the arm is relatively slow.

Do you know if increasing kF would, in general, increase the % output tied to desired velocity? Do you know if there is a way to lower the oscillations resulting from increasing kF? What is a reasonable kF?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T21:02:07.763Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":92,"readers_count":91,"score":23.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"Ryan Elchahal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":38127,"username":"tylerhedge","name":"tyler hedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172372,"name":"Eli Barnett","username":"Oblarg","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oblarg/{size}/161674_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T21:07:22.763Z","cooked":"

Feedforward shouldn’t cause oscillations unless your commanded accelerations/velocities are not physically reasonable.

It’s not super helpful to talk about kF, since feedforward for any nontrivial mechanism is not just a single gain. I would avoid the kF gain on your PID controller entirely, and do the entire feedforward calculation yourself on the RIO (WPILib has utilities for this). The relevant gains there are kS, kG, kV, and kA - corresponding to stiction, gravity, velocity, and acceleration.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T21:08:00.357Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":97.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"Eli Barnett","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12381,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/8","custom_user_title":"Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172387,"name":"tyler hedge","username":"tylerhedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T21:24:24.824Z","cooked":"

Im going to defer all the kF stuff to @Oblarg because he is gonna be more help than I am on that. The fact that your arm is not reaching its cruise velocity indicates to me that your PID loop is not properly tuned. increasing your P gain should increase your arm speed.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-24T21:24:24.824Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":82,"readers_count":81,"score":26.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"tyler hedge","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54521,"username":"Relch06","name":"Ryan Elchahal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/9","custom_user_title":"6377 Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172461,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-24T23:32:03.373Z","cooked":"
Oblarg:

I would avoid the kF gain on your PID controller entirely, and do the entire feedforward calculation yourself on the RIO

With Motion Magic, I’d expect it’s generally better to use the onboard kF instead of WPILib’s kV because the profile is generated on the controller, so there’s extra latency with calculating kV on the roboRIO. With that said, since this is an arm, you should definitely use WPILib’s ArmFeedforward class for kG and optionally kS, and pass the output into Motion Magic using the arbitrary feedforward parameter: Motor Controller Closed Loop — Phoenix documentation. If you use the onboard kF, keep the ArmFeedforward kV set to 0.

Relch06:

I began messing with a kF term (which had been set to zero prior)

Something to note, kF and kG combined should do most of the work to get to the target without oscillations, so you should tune those before tuning PID.

You can experimentally find kG and follow our documentation to calculate kF: Motor Controller Closed Loop — Phoenix documentation

Or you can use sysid to find kV and kG: Introduction to System Identification — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation (wpilib.org). Your kV would need to be scaled to the correct units for kF; if kV is Volts/(ticks/100ms), then kF should be kV * 1023/12.0. kG may also need to be scaled from volts to percent output (divide by 12.0).

Elchahal","username":"Relch06","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-25T15:27:14.712Z","cooked":"

Thanks so much for the detailed response!

The linked “calculate kF” docs uses the following as an example for calculating a Feed-forward gain so that 75% motor output is calculated when the requested speed is 7112 native units per 100ms:

F-gain = (75% X 1023) / 7112 F-gain = 0.1079

Where does 1023 come from? Is this encoder ticks? If so, for a falcon, would I use 2048 as there are 2048 steps per rotation for the falcon internal encoder?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-25T15:27:14.712Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":59,"readers_count":58,"score":16.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"Ryan Elchahal","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54521,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172766,"name":"tyler hedge","username":"tylerhedge","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/b5e925/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-25T15:34:24.709Z","cooked":"

Iirc falcons map their output from -1023 to 1023 where 1023 is full output. Its mapping -1 to 1 onto the range that falcons understand

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2023-03-25T15:34:24.709Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":50,"readers_count":49,"score":25.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":431615,"topic_slug":"kf-tuning","display_username":"tyler hedge","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":54521,"username":"Relch06","name":"Ryan Elchahal","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38127,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6377 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/kf-tuning/431615/12","custom_user_title":"6377 Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3172809,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-25T17:11:54.649Z","cooked":"

+1000 to this. TUNE YOUR KF FIRST. You can’t throw kF on top of a full PID loop and expect to immediately return results.

In general, I recommend going F - P - D - I when tuning. So, comment out your constants, calculate kF, and then go from there. Using arbitrary feedforward to add a gravity compensation kG is a good idea. You can probably skip kS if you don’t want to find it, it’s generally small.
